title: Metric Forensics: A Multi-Level Approach for Mining Volatile Graphs

author: Keith Henderson, Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory

segmentation: Yeah, I didn't see Strasburg pitch.
He actually got scratched.
Sorry, so to motivate this a little bit we kind of have we're in this new world where we can actually sense a lot of things very quickly, but sometimes it's hard to analyze those things, so I.
A good concrete example is IP traffic.

We can put a tap on a network and see lots of packets go by, and we can specialize those packets and maybe we can build a graph out of them, but the graph is changing really rapidly and we'd like to be able to detect things that are happening in it, but the data is a little too big to store all of it, and maybe summarizing it isn't satisfactory.

So also phone calls and text messages, or sort of clear thing that's new that we can sense in store and then social networking is starting to get pretty fast with things like Twitter if you build a graph out of tweets.
Using mentions that graph changes.
Quickly, so we're going to ask for a few things.
We'd like to be able to quickly find things when they happen, so we'll call that effectiveness.
I guess we want to run algorithms that are linear in the number of edges, say, or near linear in the number of edges.
And also we'd like to be able to sort of apply this to lots of problems and also use lots of tools.
So what I'm going to present is more of a framework that hopefully is flexible, and you can sort of plug in whatever algorithms and metrics you like so you can check our related work section.
There are a lot of there's a lot of cool work in this area, but we didn't find anything that kind of did all of these.
I think our closest sibling is a tool called Red Back, which isn't publicly available, but there are some good papers on it, and it does some time series analysis of graph.
Apps.
So I'm going to talk about the problem, the solution, and.
Stuff just like normal, so will start at the just.
Basically we have these edges coming by and an edge in its simplest form is just a source in the target and then the time during which that edge existed.

So a concrete example again would be you have a tap on your enterprise network an you have some software that's running in a pipeline to session highs packets and so a given session might be an edge and you have a time during which that that edge existed.

We might have other attributes, but for now we'll kind of ignore those and we want to find interesting events and then the other thing we like to do is be able to find out who's responsible for those events.
We want to actually do Attribution and the hypothesis that drives this is that there are certain strange behaviors that an individual can do that will be will show up at the top level.

So for example, if you're scanning an IP range, then the network administrator might see a lot fewer components in the in the graph then or than normal because all of a sudden everyone's getting hit by one person.
And so the general idea, in order to make this feasible, is that we can't watch everyone all the time.
We can't calculate heavyweight metrics like centrality metrics on every node constantly.
So will cheat by only doing that when we think something's happening, and to find out when something is happening will calculate a bunch of really fast global level metrics.
In the graph, so this is sort of the manager friendly version of what we're doing.

We start on the left and we have sort of this volatile system and and we're going to split it up into a series of graphs and I'll talk a little more specifically later, and then we'll run some cheap global metrics on the graphs.
Things are used to like average degree and some eigenvalue analysis, and then we have some analysis techniques that will apply, and again, this is all kind of plug and play, so whatever you like.
But these would be stuff like time series analysis, which there are obviously lots of tools.
And then will basically keep going down as we find events we will start to do more severe analysis.

So we'll start running community metrics and local metrics and try to find out who's actually responsible for these things, and then eventually hopefully the analyst is happy because he has some characteristic behaviors and some events and maybe who is.
Sponsible for those events.
So.
Here's how we represent things.
We have nodes.
These can be IP addresses or cell phones or whatever.
They can come and go, but they'll have a unique identifier.
There's a beyond the scope problem of dynamically assigned IP's, but yeah we don't look at that here.
And then we have edges which might just pop in and go away.
Or they might be duration full.
They might have weights and So what?
We'll kind of define as our basic unit is a snapshot graph, which is whatever is happening right now, but that's often not interesting, especially with instantaneous edges.
So we're going to instead take a bunch of those and mash them together into a summary graph, and so we kind of cheated and just use a simple heuristic.

But there was an interesting poster on Saturday about how to choose the size for those summary graphs, which I think is a lot better than what we did, but some of the some of the ways you can go from a snapshot graph to a summary graph would be just to add up the adjacency matrix matrices over all those snapshots.
There are lots of other ways.
We tried a lot of them.
And then we have, as I mentioned before, sort of these categories of metrics going from cheap to expensive.
So we have these kind of graph level metrics.

I'm going to list some of these next slide and then we have community type metrics and then these sort of heavyweight local metrics, which might include going back and looking at sort of full packet capture and trying to maybe spending some analysts time on this stuff so these can be expensive both computationally and also in terms.
Other resources, so here's some examples.
So global metrics you've seen all of these before.
All the ones here are pretty much linear in the number of edges.
Things like how many components there are.
The top 20 eigenvalues of the adjacency matrix articulation points are pretty nice and easy to find for the Community metrics you can kind of run any graph clustering algorithm you like.
There are obviously lots of them, but then you can pull some metrics out, like how many communities there are, how quickly those communities are changing.
How many of the nodes are in the biggest community?
And then these sort of heavier weight local metrics.
So there are lots of ways to calculate centrality and importance.
The oddball is a tool that was created recently that sort of learns these power laws on graphs and then can find nodes that don't obey those power laws.
So the analysis part of it is again sort of whatever you like.
You can sort of plug in, so we've looked at a lot of different things, including everything that I'm going to list here.
But so if you if you take one of those metrics.
In this case, the average degree for a proximity network and you just plotted overtime, you'll see you know normal time series stuff, and so we can apply normal time series techniques.
We can do auto regression, we can do fractal dimension for your Fourier analysis, and wavelets.
All of this stuff is pretty straightforward, and.
We done the other thing we can do is take metrics in pairs.
So here I'm doing.

It's a scatter plot of the top two eigenvalues for an IP network, and I've colored the the nodes based on time, which is sort of helpful because it allows us to differentiate between sort of the general shape that we would see in the correlation between those and then sort of some of these behaviors.
So every day we seem to revisit this spot, so we might call that sort of normal characteristic operational mode of this network.
Enterprise Network, But then we see this sort of strange thing here where the correlation seems to break and there's there's sort of a dip.
There's actually another one that's similar to it behind it, and there are a couple others over here, so I will come back to these a little bit later in some of our experiment slides.
And then the last thing we can do.
That's kind of the most expensive is eventually you get an analyst and you say, well, in the period identified, here's what the graph actually looked like.
So we put together this sort of dynamic visualization tool.
This is a simple version of it.
We can add colors and labels and stuff, but it's sort of.
You're seeing the graph as it actually is, and I made it move because I thought that was nice, and so an analyst could look at this and say, OK well, so for example, this IP here at the bottom is a.
Very active sync, so lots of connection or lots of connections.
Go to that IP address.
It turns out this is a DNS server.
This is a very active source.
This is a very heavy edge that seems to persist throughout this.
And so an analyst might be interested in seeing those things again.
I don't have the labels on here because they're proprietary, but I will have some labels later.
So that's kind of the general framework.
I'm going to talk now about some things that we found out just.
Some results, so we had a few datasets.
The sort of main one is this enterprise network trace, which was a weeks worth of data collected at a conference.
There was a tap at the Exterier and one internally or one or two internally.
The next one is from the reality mining data.

It's the Bluetooth proximity devices so that you have these Bluetooth devices and every five minutes or so they scan for other Bluetooth devices, some of which are not instrumented and so formed a network from that and the last one is more IP traffic from Lawrence Berkeley.
It's on a single port, but it's a lot sort of busier across that port so that one is only an hours worth but still has 9 million edges.
So generally we're looking at millions of edges, but over relatively decent periods of time, so we would consider these not to be large graphs at any particular time.
But if you're if you're monitoring a network over the course of months or years, these things get big pretty quickly.
And again, the window sizes we just sort of pick them according to a heuristic, but I think we can do better.
That in the future.
So this is kind of the raw.
The first thing you get out, so this is about you know 3020 or 30 global metrics and you're seeing the time series that come out of those.
You can see that there's sort of these diurnal type affects.
Which are, you know, to be expected.
There are lots of things that very simple analysis will find, like autoregression is going to find these big spikes in series.
We can see also that a lot of them are highly correlated.
The sensor went down here.

It turns out in this case this was a single internal machine connecting to a single external machine about 12,000 times over the course of a minute, and it was on a BitTorrent port, so it was probably a client that went awry.
But yeah, so here the sensors down and there are some other sort of strange things that we see.

As we go across, but to look a little more closely we I'm going to present just a few of the kinds of things that we've started to find in terms of weird occurrences or things that were at least surprised us.
So one of the things we can do is just these scatterplots.
So this is the biggest eigenvalue, and this is the second biggest eigenvalue for the Lawrence Berkeley data.
And here you see again the visualization.
But now we have some IPS labeled and there's some color, so there's some things you can tune on the visualization.
But what's happening is normally the big eigenvalues will track some phenomenon in the graph.
So for example, a really heavy edge or.

I know that has high total weight or a component that has high total weight and when one of those things is changing but the rest of the graph is staying the same, you will tend to see something like this horizontal line.
So here Lambda one is changing, but Lambda 2 isn't well.

At some point Lambda one becomes small enough that it swaps roles because we're sorting with Lambda two and so now Lambda two is sort of doing that change and so we see this as sort of a, you know, changing of the dominant phenomenon and of course it depends on how you.

The weights, but it turns out that it kind of doesn't because regardless of how you weight the graph or build the summaries, we still see sort of this thing that's happening, so these are sort of three different schemes for waiting the graph, and we always see this elbow and all of them, so that we think is sort of an inch.
Sting type thing.
Another thing that's actually related so we can track correlation.

So what you're seeing here is the correlation coefficient with the biggest eigenvalue for a whole bunch of other metrics, and we're looking at that region that vertical region from before, and we see that normally the big eigenvalue in this network tracks some really heavy edge, but during that.
It has very little variance at all, but it tracks nothing.
There's no metric that it seems to be correlated with, so we can look for these broken correlations, and we can do this in kind of an automatic way, and that's that's easy enough.
Again to find something.
That is strange.

Another nice technique is fractal dimension, which measures sort of the burstiness in the data, and so humans sort of tend to communicate with each other and do things with a certain fractal dimension.

And as you can see from the enterprise network, even though there are all these sort of daily effects and stuff, generally the fractal dimension is about the same with the exception of here where it drops really low for awhile, and it turns out that's related to a prolonged spike that doesn't look bursty.
It's sort of a low level, but prolong Spike, so that's.
Another tool at our disposal for finding interesting events in zoo.
In on them.

So in terms of Community analysis here, what I'm showing is again that same region an on the X axis, we still have the big eigenvalue, but then we ran cross associations, which is an information based graph clustering algorithm and so the Y axis is showing what percentage of the nodes were placed in the biggest group that cross associations found, and so we find there's sort of this normal mode of behavior again where the eigenvalue sit somewhere around 25 and about half of the nodes are in the big group.
But then by clustering we see that sometimes we have these sort of exceptional cases.
There for some reason everyone is put into the same cluster and we don't know why exactly, but this would be these would be some nodes that we would want to look at when we when we dive down deeper.
We can also this is just K means clusters that I've done so we can get outliers pretty easily here.
These guys are interesting.
It turns out that every 15 minutes on the dot during that.
The the big eigenvalue dropped by about 5 and we have no idea why.
But again, it's sort of interesting we think.
So at the local level, so this is an oddball which I mentioned before, and it's a nice technique for finding nodes in the graph that aren't doing what everyone else is doing in the graph.

So here instead of time, each dot is a particular node in the graph, and we're looking at how many neighbors it has basically plus plus one for itself, and then how many edges exist in the induced subgraphs from those neighbors will call that the ego net, and so the blue line here is based as exponent, about 2.
Which means that basically those are cliques and this makes sense in a proximity network because a lot of times if all of you have sensors, you're all in the same room, and so you all see each other.

But then there's sort of this other cluster here, which is probably more normal where you're sensing some devices that are not instrumented, and some that are, and so there's you have some nice exponent here that's in between and then these guys are outliers.

They are stars, so they have a lot of neighbors, but those neighbors don't see each other, and in particular their lightweight, which is from another plot that I'm not showing that has the weights of them.
So this is, you know, again, sort of.
The more local analytics that we might.
Do thank you.
So runtime I think is is the big win here.

So if you look at the observation window for each of these, it was about a weeks worth of network trace data like a years worth of Bluetooth activity and then an hours worth of network data for the Lawrence Berkeley.
But we're able to calculate all of our global metrics in fractions of the time.
In the worst case, about 10% of the time, so we could even add some N log N type metrics on there if we wanted to do path lengths or something.
And it's kind of no big deal.
So what we really really like to be able to do this quickly and on bigger networks hopefully too.
So.
I think in conclusion you know this multi level thing is probably going to be the way to go.

We seem to we tend to like it because it does allow you to be scalable and to track these things, but really look into the graph deeply at some points and I think that real graphs have these oddities and it's kind of fun to go in and find them.
And it's also useful for network administrators to be able to look at the.
So I can take questions or you can just watch my little Galaxy for awhile.
